data.text: Contents
Purpose

To provide guidance and support to all relevant medical staff who are responsible for the planning or consideration of the deactivation of Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillators (ICDs) as part of preparation for or during end of life care.
To provide clarity and direction regarding the process to follow when requesting an end of life ICD deactivation and who to contact to enable this to be performed.
Definition/background

An ICD is a small device usually fitted in the chest, or abdomen, which connects to the heart. They are used to treat life threatening heart rhythms such as Ventricular Tachycardia and Ventricular Fibrillation, and are fitted in cardiac patients who have experienced or are at high risk of developing these abnormal rhythms.
An ICD continuously monitors the heart rhythm and if an abnormal rhythm is detected, the device automatically initiates treatment in one of two ways:

Anti-Tachycardia Pacing (ATP) – The device will initiate a series of fast paced beats to try and interrupt the cycle of the arrhythmia causing a break and aim to return the heart to normal rhythm without the need for a shock.
Shock – The device will send an electrical impulse or ‘shock' to the heart to return the heart rhythm back to normal (defibrillation).
**It is possible for a device to treat an arrhythmia with both types of therapy dependent on how the patient's device is programmed.**
However, patients fitted with ICDs may suffer from progressive diseases that may reach a stage where it is no longer appropriate for the device to provide these types of therapy.

This could be for several reasons (see Section 7 – Considerations for ICD Deactivation) but particularly as dying patients are at risk of receiving ineffective and painful electric shocks from the ICD if they develop abnormal rhythms in their terminal phase of illness. This can be distressing for the patient, family, friends and carers.
Scope
This clinical guidance applies to any patient fitted with an Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator (ICD), who is considered to be at end of life and requires device deactivation.
Roles and responsibilities – staffing and training
The Medical Team are responsible for:
Being aware and compliant with this clinical guidance.
Deciding which patients may be appropriate for device deactivation (consulting with a multi-disciplinary clinical device team where appropriate).
Liaising with the Cardiac Physiologists regarding patients who require device deactivation and the planning to ensure this is achieved effectively.
Ensuring the correct request for ICD deactivation is fully completed (including appropriate signatures) and returned to the Cardiac Physiology team in a timely manner.
Ensuring the patient and/or their family/relatives are given adequate and clear information regarding ICD Deactivation.

Ensuring consent to ICD Deactivation is gained from the patient or Next of Kin, Power of Attorney where possible, and if not possible that appropriate documentation is undertaken to ensure the decision is made in the best interests of the patient.
Ensuring the plan of care is clearly and accurately documented in the patient's medical notes/record, including any prescribed ICD settings (if not standard) where appropriate.
**The Consultant holds ultimate responsibility for ensuring medical staff follow this document**
Cardiac Physiologists deemed competent in ICD deactivation are required to:
Be aware and compliant with this clinical guidance.
Ensure they have the correct information about the device manufacturer, model and mode.
Ensure they have received fully completed and signed documents requesting deactivation before performing any ICD Deactivation.
Ensure that the appropriate programmer is available for the date and time of the requested ICD deactivation, and arrange for any additional support from device manufacturers if deemed necessary.
Ensure that the patient (where appropriate) and/or family/relatives are aware of the deactivation process.
Ensure that any changes made to any device (including device deactivation) are recorded and evidenced fully on the appropriate Cardiology reporting system (Tomcat).
Ensure that the ICD Deactivation is fully and clearly documented in the patient's medical notes/record.

Ensure where appropriate, a copy of the device deactivation request and report are sent to the patient's usual device follow up centre to inform them of the deactivation via a secure nhs.net email address and to ensure suitable follow up arrangements for the device with the settings that remain active are arranged if required (For example – ensuring the continued follow up of the pacemaker function of the ICD if deemed applicable to the ongoing care plan for the patient).
Clinical instruction – consideration for ICD deactivation
All patients with ICD's in situ should be considered for deactivation when they are deemed for end of life care or being considered for a DNACPR order.
ICD Deactivation could be considered in the following circumstances:
At request of the patient, ensuring that the patient is fully aware of the implications of device deactivation and the potential consequences that may occur.

Death is expected in the near future with no further interventions planned and the delivery of a shock therapy from the ICD would be inappropriate or detrimental as the patient approaches end of life.
When the patient is being considered for transfer to a hospice or home for end of life care or a referral to the palliative care team is being considered.
If withdrawal of anti-arrhythmic drugs is required.
Clinical instruction – considerations prior to ICD deactivation

Discussions about deactivation of an ICD should take place as early as possible to avoid any unnecessary distress. This may include discussions that have taken place with the patient before the ICD was inserted. By discussing deactivation early in care planning, a planned ICD deactivation can be scheduled and the patient and their family can be informed of what to expect.
The option of ICD Deactivation should be considered by the multi-disciplinary team (MDT) in conjunction with the patient and/or family/relatives if appropriate to their care.

The patient and/or family/relatives should be fully aware of the reasons for ICD Deactivation and the subsequent consequences that may arise as a result of deactivation, alongside the benefits to the patient in this stage of their life.
It is the responsibility of the consultant and their team to fully explain the consequences of device deactivation, these being:
Deactivation itself will not cause death.
The device will still continue to provide basic bradycardia pacemaker therapies to prevent slow heart rhythms (Bradycardia).
The device will no longer provide treatment/shock therapy in the event of the occurrence of life threatening heart rhythms, such as Ventricular Fibrillation (VF) or Ventricular Tachycardia (VT).
Deactivation will not be painful.
The decision to deactivate the ICD is reversible – the ICD can be reactivated if the patients clinical situation changes.
Responsibility for the final decision to deactivate the ICD and therapies lies with one of the following:
Consultant Cardiologist
Palliative Care Consultant
Other Medical Consultant
General Practitioner (GP)
Clinical instruction – requesting an ICD deactivation

The responsible consultant and their team are required to complete the ICD Deactivation Request Form (Appendix 1) fully and completely with all of the required details, including contact information for the requestor in case the Cardiac Physiologists wish to discuss the deactivation request.

The responsible consultant and their team are responsible for ensuring the patient and/or their family/relatives are given adequate and clear information regarding ICD Deactivation and ensuring consent to ICD Deactivation is gained from the patient or Next of Kin, Power of Attorney where possible, and if not possible that appropriate documentation is undertaken to ensure the decision is made in the best interests of the patient.
Once the ICD Deactivation Request Form is fully completed, the Cardiac Physiologists should be informed of the decision to deactivate the ICD.
The completed request form should be hand delivered to the Cardiac Centre -A210) (Contact Extension 4185), and given to one of the Cardiac Physiologists.

Alternatively as long as the form is fully completed and contact information is left in case of the Cardiac Physiologists needing to contact the requestor to discuss the deactivation request, forms can be emailed to mse.mehtpacingicd@nhs.net .
**PLEASE DO NOT EMAIL URGENT OR TIME CRITICAL DEACTIVATION REQUESTS – THESE SHOULD BE HAND DELIVERED AND DISCUSSED WITH THE CARDIAC PHYSIOLOGY TEAM DIRECTLY**

Planned ICD Deactivation is achieved by the use of specialist device specific equipment, and therefore can only be carried out in a hospital setting. Therefore forward planning is essential, where appropriate, to ensure deactivation is performed in a time appropriate manner. In circumstances where in-hospital deactivation is not possible or suitable, please refer to Section 9 for advice regarding Emergency ICD Deactivation.
Clinical instruction – performing an ICD deactivation

Where a planned ICD Deactivation is requested the Cardiac Physiologist will attend to the inpatient at their bedside with the required specialist equipment appropriate to their device to perform the deactivation.
The Cardiac Physiologist will, where requested and appropriate, allow the patient to have their family/relatives present for the deactivation should they wish to do so.

The Cardiac Physiologist will ensure that the patient (where appropriate) and/or family/relatives are aware of the deactivation process, and answer any questions they may have prior to performing the deactivation.

The Cardiac Physiologist will ensure that any changes made to any device (including device deactivation) are recorded and evidenced fully on the appropriate Cardiology reporting system (Tomcat) and in the patient's medical notes/record.

Where necessary, the Cardiac Physiologist will send a copy of the device deactivation request and report to the patient's usual device follow up centre to inform them of the deactivation via a secure nhs.net email address and to ensure suitable follow up arrangements for the device with the settings that remain active are arranged if required (For example – ensuring the continued follow up of the pacemaker function of the ICD if deemed applicable to the ongoing care plan for the patient).
Clinical instruction – emergency/out of hours ICD deactivation
There are situations where emergency device deactivation is required outside of normal working hours of the Cardiac Physiology Team (9-5pm Monday to Friday) or in the community setting.
Management of implantable cardioverter defibrillator – end of life / 17007
Page  of
If deactivation by a Cardiac Physiologist is not available, for emergency procedures only, a magnet can be applied directly over the generator site.
If deactivation by a Cardiac Physiologist is not available then a magnet can be used in these situations.
Medical staff should obtain verbal consent and should clearly communicate to the patient and/or family/relative the reasons and consequences of magnet use:
Shock therapies will be temporarily disabled (for duration of application)
It is safe to apply a magnet to an ICD when it is actively shocking.

Please see the below diagrams to illustrate the correct application of a magnet to both a transvenous ICD and a subcutaneous ICD (S-ICD).If any concerns or further advice is required out of hours then cardiology advice is available by contacting the Cardiology Registrar at the Essex Cardiothoracic Centre (Telephone: 0845 155 3111, Bleep 9010).

**Some devices are only inhibited by a magnet for 8 hours; If the surgery is to be prolonged (>8 Hours), the magnet should be removed for  seconds (in which the device will reactivate) and be reapplied every 7 Hours**
Magnets can be obtained from the following locations:
Cardiac Centre (A210)
Theatres – Theatre 2 Anaesthetic Room (Located on the CD Cupboard)
Acute Medical Unit (A204) – (Located in the CD Cupboard)
Palliative Care Nurses (Community)
Trigger Response Team (Located in their Grab Bag)
Hospital Out of Hours Office
Farleigh Hospice
10 Non deactivated ICD's in the dying patient
In some circumstances patients with ICDs in situ will die prior to device deactivation having been instigated or planned.
In the majority of these cases, shock therapy will not occur due to the nature of a typical heart rhythm in a dying patient.

In the event that a shock therapy is triggered and delivered to the patient during the late stages of dying, the number of shocks delivered will be limited by the model and type of device in situ and the programmed settings, however typically these are limited to maximum of 6 shocks.

When a patient dies with an active ICD in situ, the mortuary team must be informed so that they can liaise with the Cardiac Physiology Team at the earliest convenience as the device may need permanent deactivation prior to removal by the mortuary staff, autopsy or cremation.
NB. ALL DEVICES MUST BE EXPLANTED BEFORE A BODY IS CREMATED
11 Infection prevention

All staff will adhere to Trust guidelines on infection prevention at all times; such as hand washing, the use of sterile procedures, and additional infection prevention measures when required i.e. gloves and aprons and effective decontamination of all non-disposable equipment between patients
12 Equality and diversity
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
An Equality Impact Assessment form is attached as Appendix
13 Monitoring and audit
Each document must outline the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

The device will continue to provide slow heart rhythm support if needed (basic pacemaker function).

Who benefits from this change and how?

All patients with CIED's implanted as they approach End of Life – process has been updated in line with updated British Heart Rhythm Society (BHRS) Guidelines. Update of process and policy will clarify how to manage patients of this nature when they are approaching End of Life.
